item.title: Report E-2025010244
item.description:
Report E-2025010244

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-23T21:13:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-21
  • City: ROMULUS
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics contacted ERTS regarding a two metal totes containing hazardous product, Unisol Liquid Red BK 50. A contractor dispatched and observed an estimated 0.5-gallon release from two metal totes that impacted 1’x1’ areas on tops and sides of the totes, the wooden trailer floor, and the concrete dock floor. One of the totes had a loose bung cap that was mis-threaded, and the other tote had a loose lid that was easily tightened. The contractor used simple green to clean-up the release and performed slosh tests on the totes. One 55-gallon DM of waste was generated containing impacted rags, floor debris, and PPE. The totes will ship onto the consignee. XPO will manage all waste created from the response. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident.

item.title: Report E-2025010212
item.description:
Report E-2025010212

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-23T21:13:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-18
  • City: EL PASO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LEP experienced a UN2735 Niax Catalyst C-232 release from a 55-gallon metal drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of product released to a 6’ x 5’ area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. The damage drum was placed into a 95-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents and pads were then utilized to clean the impacted area. All impacted absorbents and cleanup debris were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage

item.description:
Report E-2025010208

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-23T21:13:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-17
  • City: KNOXVILLE
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics contacted ERTS regarding crushed boxes with plastic jugs containing hazardous product, Kathon. A contractor dispatched and observed an estimated 2-gallons of product released onto the wooden trailer floor in a 4’x4’ area and the concrete beneath the trailer in a 10’x3’ area as a result of improper blocking and bracing. The contractor neutralized the release using vinegar and containerized two empty jugs last containing product along with absorbents, cardboard, pallet pieces, and PPE. One 55-gallon DF was generated for waste disposal. XPO will manage all waste created from the response. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. The crew utilized neutralizing agent and absorbents to remediate the site. The damaged drum was containerized in one (1) 95-gallon overpack and all other waste was collected in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025010205
item.description:
Report E-2025010205

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-23T21:13:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-15
  • City: CREST HILL
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 56ft-by-6ft area of the trailer floor and the dock floor and estimated that seventy-five (75) gallons of material was released due to a forklift puncturing one (1) 55-gallon metal drum of Hi-Temp 1200 causing it to knock over into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum of PBTCA damaging it. Before Clean Harbors’ arrival, Dayton Freight personnel had placed both damaged drums into two (2) 85-gallon overpacks. Clean Harbors personnel deployed the neutralizer sodium bicarbonate and granular absorbents to the impacted area. They used a pH strip to test the paint inside the metal drum which resulted in a neutral result. All impacted absorbents were placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to contractor demobilization. After departing off site, Clean Harbors personnel were asked to return to assist with the transfer of the contents of one (1) 85-gallon metal overpack drum to a one (1) 85-gallon poly drum due to the corrosive nature of the contained material. One (1) 85-gallon ploy drum was used to contain neutralizers and granular absorbents utilized during the transfer. Clean Harbors personnel staged one (1) 55-gallon poly drum, one (1) 85-gallon metal drum, and three (3) 85-gallon poly drums onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: On January 14, 2025, one (1) 5-gallon drum of UN3266 was damaged and released approximately two (2) cups of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Works, Inc. (EWI) to remediate the impacted site. Crews utilized hand tools, absorbents, soda ash, and a pH testing strip to remediate the impacted trailer. One (1) 55-gallon drum of cleanup debris and impacted material, and one (1) 55-gallon drum containing the damaged product were staged onsite.

  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Upon arrival at the destination terminal, this tote was discovered leaking inside the trailer. The tote was immediately turned on it's side to prevent further release. After investigation, it was determined that this tote was damaged due to a load shift during transit. An empty tote was used as dunnage to protect the tote and a piece of wood on the skid broke and was pushed into the tote, causing puncture. The material was a thick liquid and was contained to the trailer floor. The material was absorbed using absorbent material and placed into an overpack container for later disposal.

item.description:
Report X-2025010709

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-23T21:13:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-11
  • City: ANCHORAGE
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 1/13/2025 at approximately 1030, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 261690 at the ramp facility in Anchorage, reporting undeclared dangerous goods. The shipment consisted of one fiberboard box, containing 10 inner boxes, and each of those contained 10 plastic bags containing safety matches. The shipment was flagged and opened by the Customs division. The Commercial Invoice identified the inner contents as "arithmetical bar"; however, Customs discovered a contradicting image in X-ray screening. Upon making the discovery, Customs submitted the package to FedEx Dangerous Goods department for proper reporting. The shipment was not prepared in accordance with IATA Regulations missing the required markings, labeling, packaging and paperwork. The shipment is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

item.title: Report E-2025010200
item.description:
Report E-2025010200

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-23T21:13:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-10
  • City: CHICAGO HEIGHTS
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 20000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal BCH experienced a UN3082 Rhonox Herbicide release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 165-gallons of product released due to a forklift puncture. The entire trailer floor, a 150’ x 30’ area of the concrete lot below, and 4 drains and 1 catch basin were impacted. All drains lead to the catch basin where the material was contained. The crew utilized a vac truck to remove the product from the catch basin and drains leading to it. Absorbents were deployed to the trailer and concrete lot and worked in. Once the drains were done, absorbent boom was placed in them to collect any residual material. The product remaining the damaged tote was pumped out and the damaged tote was cut up and containerized. Crew returned to site and inspected the drains and flushed and vacuumed them out again. Additional wastewater was generated to be offloaded into totes. Samples were collected to confirm that no residual material remains in the catch basin and samples were collected from the nearby retention pond as well as a precaution. All wastewater was offloaded into totes and all solid cleanup debris was containerized into 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage

  • Description: When the warehouseman can in for work he went out to inspect the Wearhouse and found a poly drum on a pallet with material on the floor under the skid. He then put down some absorbent and called our emergency response. A team was dispatched to the facility and arrived at 0900 et. They determined that the crew did not have the proper PPE to handle the material. The material was contained and not actively leaking. There was not a crew available with the proper PPE until the next morning and they showed up at 0600et and began cleaning up the material and placing the drum into a salvage drum. the material was cleaned up with absorbent material and placed into the proper shipping container to be disposed of. The clean up was completed by 0830et.
